Bruce Lee had a close relationship with other Hollywood actors of color, and they supported each other in many ways in the industry.

One of Lee's close friends and mentors was James Coburn, who was also an actor and martial artist. Coburn helped Lee in many aspects of his career, such as introducing him to different martial arts experts, helping him develop his fighting style, and even co-writing the script for one of his movies.

Another friend of Lee's was Jim Kelly, who was also a martial artist and actor. Kelly appeared in several Blaxploitation films in the 1970s and became famous for his role in the movie "Enter the Dragon," alongside Lee. The two actors became close friends during the filming of the movie, and Kelly later became a prominent martial arts instructor.

Lee was also friends with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the famous basketball player who played a prominent role in the movie "Game of Death." Abdul-Jabbar was one of Lee's students, and he trained in martial arts under Lee's guidance. Lee also respected Abdul-Jabbar's athletic abilities and incorporated some of his moves into his fighting style.

Apart from these actors, Lee also had a good relationship with other Hollywood actors of color, such as Fred Williamson, Rudy Ray Moore, and Ron Van Clief. They often discussed their experiences in the industry and supported each other in their careers.

Overall, Bruce Lee's relationship with other Hollywood actors of color was based on mutual respect and a shared passion for martial arts and acting. They supported each other in many ways, from helping each other land roles to sharing their knowledge and experiences in the industry.
